pros: Amazing culture. Proud to be an employee.
cons: Can be chaotic at times. Opportunities for advancement are limited.

pros: Good working culture, one of the best places to work in toronto.
cons: Too many management changes in the last few years

review_title: Not a place to grow your career
pros: Good benefits, all paid for.
cons:
Not a place to progress your career, especially if you are a woman who has plans to become pregnant. Was promised a new role and immediately ignored/revoked when I announced my pregnancy. No support from HR or the career development person. Very disappointing.

This is not a place to grow your career but if you are looking for a low stress and old school company with poor support of DEI, this is the place to be.

pros: The OMA is making a significant difference for health care in Ontario. It's a good place to work.
cons: There's only a few people doing each area of expertise and there is a never-ending amount of work. The OMA is more like a collection of small organizations than a single org.

job_title: Education Engagement Specialist in Toronto, ON
pros: Nice downtown Yorkville location, but only if you travel by transit.
cons: Micromanagement and not able to see the bigger picture. Stodgy.

pros: Great working culture and environment
cons: Salaries not competitive and working hours can be too long

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Good culture, inclusiveness, internal hiring, meaningful work, job security and longevity.
cons: Political, can get a bit crazy at times, departments are overworked

pros: Excellent team culture, and growth opportunities.
cons: Hard to think of any

review_title: Toxic culture and lack of real leadership
job_title: Middle Management Position in Seattle, WA
pros: Good benefits. Nice office (before pandemic).
cons:
There are so many things to say here. But the most striking one is that OMA has toxic work culture. Some managers are highly arrogant and have a lot of egos. Micromanagement from the very top!

All revolves around politics. Management will ask for your feedback but when you are honest to share, they will use it against you as being negative. HR is powerless because it’s driven by the senior leadership who pays them.

I have seen a lot of backstabbing because of political influences across the whole organization. Selfishness (not leadership) from the very top!

pros: Pay, work culture in my department, leadership in my department
cons: The OMA isn't one organization, it's at least 5 and they all have different cultures. Be aware of what you're joining

job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Toronto, ON
pros: Good place to work in the city
cons: Not so good place to work

pros:
OMA has good staff policies and some really lovely people work here.
It is nice to work at an organization that's primary purpose is to HELP physicians
cons:
1) It all depends on your manager. There are some great managers here and some really dysfunctional ones. HR does not provide good support for management.
2)  Having a stable (randed) income might have made  organization a bit complacent - management jumps to adopt overbuilt solutions when these are not always necessary.
3) Generally, the organization is scared of change (although it recognizes the need) and enables staff who are resistant to change slow down and derail efforts.

pros: The people are definitely the best part of working here, and while the organization has been through a rough few years, there is definitely a sense of the tone changing. The organization is aware of its shortcomings and currently working to actively address them both with staff and members. This is making for a fairly exciting and busy time to work here.
cons: Historically, a number of people have been promoted into management based soley on their subject matter expertise. While they're smart, some of them are terrible people managers and this shows. The organization seems aware of this, and appears to be attempting to bridge those gaps.

pros: Good Benefits, Summer hours for a few days in July/August.
cons: Low pay range, Smaller association therefore little room to move up.    Most job titles jump from Admin to Management.  Very few job in between (i.e. coordinators, analysts etc.)

job_title: Administrator/Senior Administrative Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Great people, good benefits, opportunities to grow professionally
cons: Usual issues re office politics and communication with staff

pros: Good location, otherwise not much of anything positive. Organization is very old and it shows. At least it's near a subway station.
cons: Slow to change, still running old technology. Heavily ingrained in a culture of office politics. A great place to go if you don't want to be exposed to cutting-edge anything.

pros: Amazing people to work with
cons: Can get quite stressful at times

review_title: Highly Political External Environment, But A Good Place to Work
pros: Great people to work with
cons: The OMA is in the press all the time, and often in very stressful ways.

pros: Worked with a professional and supportive team of individuals.
cons: Difficult to advance within the company at that time.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: big organization and not for profit
cons: no room for growth, lack of diversity

pros: Good benefits, competitive salary.
cons: Very political, poor recognition, constant reorgs
